reviews.review_msg: Do not take this course. There were so many weekly assignments to be done as both an individual and as a group. A total of 50% of the course's mark comes down to group work. Lectures are packed with redundant material, and the only reason for going is connecting with your group which you cannot pick. Grading at times felt random despite rubrics.

THE WORST!! Weekly group assignments, weekly individual assignments, multiple long papers, and a 10-page exam with two days to write it. Nice person, but horrible, unrealistic teaching style. I wouldn't recommend taking a class with him to anyone. Hopefully, I can save someone from making this mistake.
Provides multiple options to demonstrate knowledge of course material. Mark also is open to feedback from students and will try to organize the course in response to students' requests.

Let's you choose how you want your assignments weighted. Presentation/Case study  group assignments and were fairly easy if you had good group members (I didn't :/). Final was take home ten page assignments (go to office hours, figure out what he's looking for). Readings/lecture  waste of time after the case study (final doesn't test on them).

The syllabus and the actual course content were very different, although Mark is a very nice guy, his class was all over the place. The paper and presentation are done in a group with a fairly straight forward take-home exam. However, pop quizzes were brutal with very low averages. Lectures were dry and often went over useless quant research.

super nice guy, but other than that he is terrible. Fake news lecture was nothing what it seemed to be on syllabus when signing up for this course. He is all over the place during lecture, you really have to pay attention in order to follow what he is saying. Presentation & paper assignment is a waste of time. Find something more meaningful
